NGC6905.description: NGC 6905, also known as the Blue Flash Nebula, is a planetary nebula in the constellation Delphinus. It was discovered by William Herschel in 1784.

NGC6907.description: NGC 6907 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Capricornus. It is located at a distance of about 120 million light-years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 6907 is about 115,000 light-years across.

NGC6908.description: Superposed on the northeastern arm of NGC 6907.

NGC6910.description: NGC 6910, also known as the Inchworn Cluster,  is an open cluster in the constellation Cygnus. It was discovered by William Herschel on October 17, 1786.

NGC6913.name: Messier 29
NGC6913.description: Messier 29 or M29, also known as NGC 6913 or the Cooling Tower Cluster, is a quite small, bright open cluster of stars just south of the central bright star Gamma Cygni of a northerly zone of the sky, Cygnus. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764, and can be seen from Earth by using binoculars.

NGC6914.description: NGC 6914 is a reflection nebula located approximately 6,000 light-years away in the constellation of Cygnus, and was discovered by Édouard Stephan on August 29, 1881. Ultraviolet radiation from stars in the Cygnus OB2 association ionize the nebula's hydrogen.

NGC6919.description: NGC 6919 is an intermediate spiral galaxy in the constellation of Microscopium. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 6,458±14 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 310.7 ± 21.8 Mly (95.25 ± 6.67 Mpc).

NGC6925.description: NGC 6925 is an unbarred spiral galaxy in the constellation Microscopium of apparent magnitude 11.3. It is lens-shaped, as it lies almost edge on to observers on Earth.

NGC6933.description: This is a list of NGC objects 6001–7000 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC6934.description: NGC 6934 (also known as Caldwell 47) is a globular cluster of stars in the northern constellation of Delphinus, about 52 kilolight-years distant from the Sun. It was discovered by the German-born astronomer William Herschel on 24 September 1785.

NGC6938.description: This is a list of NGC objects 6001–7000 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC6939.description: NGC 6939 is an open cluster in the constellation Cepheus. It was discovered by William Herschel in 1798.

NGC6940.description: NGC 6940 is an open cluster in the constellation Vulpecula. It was discovered by William Herschel in 1784.

NGC6946.name: Fireworks Galaxy
NGC6946.description: NGC 6946, sometimes referred to as the Fireworks Galaxy, is a grand design, face-on intermediate spiral galaxy with a small bright nucleus, whose location in the sky straddles the boundary between the northern constellations of Cepheus and Cygnus. Its distance from Earth is about 25.2 million light-years or 7.72 megaparsecs, similar to the distance of M101 (NGC 5457) in the constellation Ursa Major.

NGC6948.description: NGC 6948 is a spiral galaxy of morphological type Sa located in the southern constellation of Indus. It was discovered by British astronomer John Herschel on 24 July 1835.

NGC6950.description: This is a list of NGC objects 6001–7000 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC6951.description: NGC 6951 (also catalogued as NGC 6952) is a barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Cepheus. It is located at a distance of about 75 million light-years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 6951 is about 100,000 light-years across.

NGC6952.description: NGC 6951 (also catalogued as NGC 6952) is a barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Cepheus. It is located at a distance of about 75 million light-years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 6951 is about 100,000 light-years across.

NGC6953.description: This is a list of NGC objects 6001–7000 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC6956.description: NGC 6956 is a barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Delphinus. It is located at a distance of about 214 million light-years from Earth.

NGC6960.name: Veil Nebula
NGC6960.description:
The Veil Nebula is a cloud of heated and ionized gas and dust in the constellation Cygnus.
It constitutes the brightest parts of the visible portion of the Cygnus Loop, a supernova remnant, many portions of which have acquired their own individual names and catalogue identifiers.

NGC6963.description: This is a list of NGC objects 6001–7000 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC6966.description: This is a list of NGC objects 6001–7000 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC6967.description: CGCG misidentifies this with NGC 6965. NED follows MCG and UGC.

NGC6970.description: NGC 6970 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Indus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 5,089±29 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 244.8 ± 17.2 Mly (75.06 ± 5.28 Mpc).

NGC6973.description: This is a list of NGC objects 6001–7000 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC6974.description:
The Veil Nebula is a cloud of heated and ionized gas and dust in the constellation Cygnus.
It constitutes the brightest parts of the visible portion of the Cygnus Loop, a supernova remnant, many portions of which have acquired their own individual names and catalogue identifiers.

NGC6975.description: NGC 6975, also known as NGC 6976, is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Aquarius. The object was discovered on 12 July 1864 by the German astronomer Albert Marth.

NGC6976.description: NGC 6975, also known as NGC 6976, is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Aquarius. The object was discovered on 12 July 1864 by the German astronomer Albert Marth.

NGC6979.description:
The Veil Nebula is a cloud of heated and ionized gas and dust in the constellation Cygnus.
It constitutes the brightest parts of the visible portion of the Cygnus Loop, a supernova remnant, many portions of which have acquired their own individual names and catalogue identifiers.

NGC6980.description: This is a list of NGC objects 6001–7000 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC6981.name: Messier 72
NGC6981.description: Messier 72 (also known as M72 or NGC 6981) is a globular cluster in the south west of the very mildly southern constellation of Aquarius.

NGC6984.description: NGC 6984 is a barred spiral galaxy located 180 million light years away in the constellation Indus.  It is a Type II Seyfert galaxy, a type of active galactic nucleus (AGN).

NGC6993.description: NGC 6993 is a large barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Capricornus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 5,824±18 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 280.2 ± 19.6 Mly (85.91 ± 6.02 Mpc).

NGC6999.description:
NGC 6999 is a S0 morphology type lenticular galaxy located 524.9 million light years from Earth in the constellation of Microscopium.
It was discovered by Albert Marth on October 19th 1864.

NGC7000.name: North America Nebula
NGC7000.description: The North America Nebula (NGC 7000 or Caldwell 20) is an emission nebula in the constellation Cygnus, close to Deneb (the tail of the swan and its brightest star) in the night sky. It is named because its shape resembles North America.

NGC7001.description: NGC 7001 is an intermediate spiral galaxy located about 300 million light-years away in the constellation Aquarius. NGC 7001 has an estimated diameter of 123,000 light-years.

NGC7002.description: NGC 7002 is a large elliptical galaxy,  and a radio galaxy, around 320 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation of Indus. The galaxy was discovered by English astronomer John Herschel on September 30, 1834.

NGC7003.description: NGC 7003 is a spiral galaxy around 220 million light-years  from Earth in the constellation Delphinus. NGC 7003 has an estimated diameter of 85,000 light-years.

NGC7004.description: NGC 7004 is a lenticular galaxy and a type 2 Seyfert galaxy around 330 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Indus. NGC 7004 has an estimated diameter of 140,000 light-years.

NGC7006.description: NGC 7006 (also known as Caldwell 42) is a globular cluster  in the constellation Delphinus. NGC 7006 resides in the outskirts of the Milky Way.

NGC7007.description: NGC 7007 is a lenticular galaxy with a small bar, around 100 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Indus. It was discovered by astronomer John Herschel on July 8, 1834.

NGC7008.description: NGC 7008 (PK 93+5.2), also known as the Fetus Nebula, is a planetary nebula with a diameter of approximately 1 light-year located at a distance of 2800 light years in northern Cygnus. It was discovered by William Herschel in 1787, in Slough, England.

NGC7009.name: Saturn Nebula
NGC7009.description: The Saturn Nebula (also known as NGC 7009 or Caldwell 55) is a planetary nebula in the constellation Aquarius. It appears as a greenish-yellowish hue in a small amateur telescope.

NGC7010.description: NGC 7010 is a massive elliptical galaxy located about 370 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Aquarius. NGC 7010 was discovered by astronomer John Herschel on August 6, 1823, and was later listed by French astronomer Guillaume Bigourdan as IC 5082.

NGC7011.description: NGC 7011 is an open star cluster located in the constellation of Cygnus.

NGC7012.description: NGC 7012 is a large, bright elliptical galaxy located about 380 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Microscopium. NGC 7012 was discovered by astronomer John Herschel on July 1, 1834.

NGC7013.description: NGC 7013 is a relatively nearby spiral or lenticular galaxy estimated to be around 37 to 41.4 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation of Cygnus. NGC 7013 was discovered by English astronomer William Herschel on July 17, 1784 and was also observed by his son, astronomer John Herschel on September 15, 1828.

NGC7014.description: NGC 7014 is an elliptical galaxy located about 210 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Indus. NGC 7014 was discovered by English astronomer John Herschel on October 2, 1834.

NGC7015.description: NGC 7015 is a spiral galaxy located about 203 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Equuleus. NGC 7015's calculated velocity is 4,881 km/s (3,033 mi/s).

NGC7016.description: NGC 7016 is an elliptical galaxy located about 480 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Capricornus. NGC 7016's calculated velocity is 11,046 km/s.

NGC7023.name: Iris Nebula
NGC7023.description: Identified as IR cirrus by Strauss, et al (1992, ApJS, 83, 29).

NGC7027.description: The 2MASX position refers to a star just east of the nebula.

NGC7028.description: Identification as NGC 7028 is very uncertain.

NGC7029.description: NGC 7029 is an elliptical galaxy located about 120 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Indus. NGC 7029 has an estimated diameter of 129,000 light-years.

NGC7030.description: NGC 7030 is a barred spiral galaxy located about 380 million light-years away in the constellation Capricornus. NGC 7030 has an estimated diameter of 133,510 light-years.

NGC7031.description: NGC 7031 is a small open cluster located in the Cygnus constellation. It was discovered by German-British astronomer William Herschel on September 21, 1788.

NGC7032.description: NGC 7032 is a spiral galaxy located about 140 million light-years away in the constellation Pavo. It has an estimated diameter of 71,370 light-years.

NGC7033.description: NGC 7033 is a lenticular galaxy located about 390 million light-years away in the constellation of  Pegasus. It is part of a pair of galaxies that contains the nearby galaxy NGC 7034.

NGC7034.description: NGC 7034 is an elliptical galaxy located about 380 million light-years away in the constellation of Pegasus. It is part of a pair of galaxies that contains the nearby galaxy NGC 7033.

NGC7035.name: NGC 7035 and NGC 7035A
NGC7035.description: NGC 7035 and NGC 7035A are a pair of interacting lenticular galaxies located around 400 to 430 million light-years away in the constellation of Capricornus. The main galaxy, NGC 7035 was discovered by astronomer Frank Muller in 1886.

NGC7037.description: NGC 7037 (also known as [KPS2012] MWSC 3477) is an open cluster located in the Cygnus constellation. It is situated north of the celestial equator and, as such, it is more easily visible from the northern hemisphere.

NGC7038.description: NGC 7038 is an intermediate spiral galaxy located about 210 million light-years away in the constellation of Indus. Astronomer John Herschel discovered NGC 7038 on September 30, 1834.

NGC7040.description: NGC 7040 is a spiral galaxy located about 260 million light-years away in the constellation of Equuleus. It has an estimated diameter of 42,600 light-years.

NGC7041.description: NGC 7041 is a lenticular galaxy located about 80 million light-years away in the constellation of Indus. NGC 7041 was discovered by astronomer John Herschel on July 7, 1834.

NGC7042.description: NGC 7042 is a spiral galaxy located about 210 million light-years away in the constellation of Pegasus. NGC 7042 is part of a pair of galaxies that contains the galaxy NGC 7043.

NGC7043.description: NGC 7043 is a barred spiral galaxy located about 200 million light-years away in the constellation of Pegasus. NGC 7043 is part of a pair of galaxies that contains the galaxy NGC 7042.

NGC7046.description: NGC 7046 is a barred spiral galaxy located 193 million light-years away in the constellation of Equuleus. With a high radial velocity of 4,130 km/s, the galaxy is drifting away from the Milky Way.

NGC7047.description: NGC 7047 is an intermediate spiral galaxy located about 270 million light-years away in the constellation of Aquarius. NGC 7047 is also classified as a LINER-type galaxy.

NGC7048.description: NGC 7048 is a planetary nebula in the constellation of Cygnus. The bright star to the lower left of the nebula is a magnitude 10.5 star, designated TYC 3589-4652-1.

NGC7049.description:
NGC 7049 is a lenticular galaxy that spans about 150,000 light-years and lies about 100 million light-years away from Earth in the inconspicuous southern constellation of Indus.
NGC 7049's unusual appearance is largely due to a prominent rope-like dust ring which stands out against the starlight behind it.

NGC7050.description: NGC 7050 is an open cluster located in the Cygnus constellation. It is situated north of the celestial equator and, as such, it is more easily visible from the northern hemisphere.

NGC7065.description: Star superposed 5.0 arcsec southwest of the nucleus.

NGC7074.description: NGC 7074 is an edge-on lenticular galaxy located about 140 million light-years away in the constellation of Pegasus. NGC 7074 was discovered by astronomer Albert Marth on October 16, 1863.

NGC7075.description: NGC 7075 is an elliptical galaxy located about 290 million light-years away in the constellation of Grus.  NGC 7075 was discovered by astronomer John Herschel on September 4, 1834.

NGC7077.description: NGC 7077 is a lenticular blue compact dwarf galaxy located about 56 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation Aquarius. Discovered by astronomer Albert Marth on August 11, 1863, the galaxy lies within the Local Void.

NGC7078.name: Messier 15
NGC7078.description: Messier 15 or M15 (also designated NGC 7078 and sometimes known as the Great Pegasus Cluster) is a globular cluster in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered by Jean-Dominique Maraldi in 1746 and included in Charles Messier's catalogue of comet-like objects in 1764.

NGC7079.description: NGC 7079 is a barred lenticular galaxy located about 110.58 million light-years away in the constellation of Grus. NGC 7079 is also classified as a LINER galaxy.

NGC7080.description: NGC 7080 is a barred spiral galaxy located about 204.5 million light-years away in the constellation of Vulpecula. It has an estimated diameter of about 100,000 light-years which would make it similar in size to the Milky Way.

NGC7081.description: NGC 7081 is a spiral galaxy located about 130 million light-years away in the constellation of Aquarius. NGC 7081 was discovered by astronomer William Herschel on October 10, 1790.

NGC7083.description: NGC 7083 is an unbarred spiral galaxy located about 134 million light-years away in the constellation of Indus. It is also classified as a flocculent spiral galaxy.

NGC7084.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7085.description: NGC 7085 is a spiral galaxy located about 365 million light-years away in the constellation of Pegasus. NGC 7085 was discovered by astronomer Albert Marth on August 3, 1864.

NGC7087.description: NGC 7087 is a barred spiral galaxy located about 215 million light-years away in the constellation of Grus. NGC 7087 was discovered by astronomer John Herschel on September 4, 1834.

NGC7088.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7089.name: Messier 2
NGC7089.description: Messier 2 or M2 (also designated NGC 7089) is a globular cluster in the constellation Aquarius, five degrees north of the star Beta Aquarii. It was discovered by Jean-Dominique Maraldi in 1746, and is one of the largest known globular clusters.

NGC7090.description: NGC 7090 is a spiral galaxy in the southern constellation of Indus located about 31 million light-years away. English astronomer John Herschel first observed this galaxy on 4 October 1834.

NGC7092.name: Messier 39
NGC7092.description: Messier 39 or M39, also known as NGC 7092, is an open cluster of stars in the constellation of Cygnus, sometimes referred to as the Pyramid Cluster. It is positioned two degrees south of the star Pi Cygni and around 9° east-northeast of Deneb.

NGC7093.description: NGC 7093 is an open cluster located in the Cygnus constellation. It was discovered by John Herschel on September 19, 1829.

NGC7095.description: NGC 7095 is a barred spiral galaxy located about 115 million light-years away in the constellation of Octans. NGC 7095 was discovered by astronomer John Herschel on September 21, 1837.

NGC7096.description: NGC 7096 is a grand-design spiral galaxy located about 130 million light-years away in the constellation of Indus. NGC 7096 is also part of a group of galaxies that contains the galaxy NGC 7083.

NGC7097.description: SGC incorrectly calls this galaxy NGC 7095.

NGC7098.description: NGC 7098 is a doubled barred spiral galaxy located about 95 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation of Octans. NGC 7098 has an estimated diameter of 152,400 light-years.

NGC7099.name: Messier 30
NGC7099.description: Messier 30 (also known as M30, NGC 7099, or the Jellyfish Cluster) is a globular cluster of stars in the southeast of the southern constellation of Capricornus, at about the declination of the Sun when the latter is at December solstice. It was discovered by the French astronomer Charles Messier in 1764, who described it as a circular nebula without a star.

NGC7100.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7110.description: NGC 7110 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Piscis Austrinus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 5044 ± 20 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 74.39 ± 5.22 Mpc (~243 million light-years).

NGC7124.description: NGC 7124 is a large spiral galaxy in the constellation of Indus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 4988 ± 15 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 240.0 ± 16.8 Mly (73.57 ± 5.16 Mpc).

NGC7129.description: NGC 7129, also known as the Small Cluster Nebula, or the Flower Bud Nebula, is a reflection nebula located 3,300 light years away in the constellation Cepheus. A young open cluster is responsible for illuminating the surrounding nebula.

NGC7130.description: NGC 7130 (also known as IC 5135) is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Piscis Austrinus. It is located at a distance of about 220 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7130 is about 188,000 light years across.

NGC7133.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7134.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7136.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7139.description: NGC 7139 is a planetary nebula located in the constellation of Cepheus. It was discovered on November 5, 1787, by astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7142.description:
NGC 7142 is an open cluster about 6,200 light-years away in the constellation Cepheus.
Due to the observational difficulties NGC 7142 presents, it has been an infrequent topic of research.

NGC7143.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7148.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7150.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7158.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7160.description: NGC 7160 is an open cluster in the constellation Cepheus. It was discovered by William Herschel on November 9, 1789.

NGC7161.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7162.description: The APMBGC position is 17 arcsec south of the nucleus.

NGC7171.description: NGC 7171 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Aquarius. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 2388 ± 24 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 35.22 ± 2.49 Mpc (~115 million light-years).

NGC7172.description: NGC 7172 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Piscis Austrinus. It is located at a distance of about 110 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7172 is about 100,000 light years across.

NGC7177.description: NGC 7177 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 801±24 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 38.6 ± 2.9 Mly (11.82 ± 0.90 Mpc).

NGC7182.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7184.description: NGC 7184 is a barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Aquarius. It is located at a distance of circa 100 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7184 is about 236,000 light years across.

NGC7190.description: NGC 7190 is a barred lenticular galaxy registered in the New General Catalogue. It is located in the direction of the Pegasus constellation.

NGC7191.description: NGC 7191 is a spiral galaxy registered in the New General Catalogue. It is located in the direction of the Indus constellation.

NGC7192.description: The APMUKS position is east of the nucleus.

NGC7196.description: NGC 7196 is an elliptical galaxy registered in the New General Catalogue. It is located in the direction of the Indus constellation, at a distance of circa 150 million light years.

NGC7199.description: NGC 7199 is a barred spiral galaxy registered in the New General Catalogue. It is located in the direction of the Indus constellation.

NGC7202.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7203.description: Misidentified in CSRG (with incorrect Dec) as NGC 7202 (a star 3.4' north).

NGC7205.description: NGC 7205 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Indus. The galaxy lies about 60 million light years away from Earth based on redshift independent methods, which means, given its apparent dimensions, that NGC 7205 is approximately 70,000 light years across.

NGC7209.description: NGC 7209 is an open cluster in the constellation Lacerta. It was discovered by William Herschel on 19 October 1787.

NGC7212.description: NGC 7212 is a triplet of galaxies located in the constellation Pegasus. They are also interacting.

NGC7213.description: NGC 7213 is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation Grus. It is located at a distance of circa 70 million light-years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7213 is about 75,000 light-years across.

NGC7217.description: NGC 7217 is an unbarred spiral galaxy in the constellation Pegasus.

NGC7222.description: NGC 7222 is a large barred spiral galaxy with a ring structure, located in the constellation Aquarius. It is located 570 million light-years away from the Solar System and was discovered by German astronomer, Albert Marth on August 11, 1864.

NGC7236.description: NGC 7236 is an interacting lenticular galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It is located at a distance of about 300 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7236 is about 150,000 light years across.

NGC7237.description: NGC 7237 is an interacting lenticular galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It is located at a distance of about 350 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7237 is about 240,000 light years across.

NGC7238.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7243.description: NGC 7243 (also known as Caldwell 16) is an open cluster and Caldwell object in the constellation Lacerta. It shines at magnitude +6.4.

NGC7248.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7250.description: NGC 7250 is an irregular galaxy located in the Lacerta constellation. It is a blue-colored galaxy with bright bursts of star formation: its star-forming rate is more than an order of magnitude greater than that of the Milky Way.

NGC7252.description: NGC 7252 is a peculiar galaxy resulting from an interaction between two galaxies that started a billion years ago. It is located 220 million light years away in the constellation Aquarius.

NGC7253.description: NGC 7253 is a pair of spiral galaxies in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered by the German-British astronomer Albert Marth on 9 September 1863.

NGC7257.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7259.description: NGC 7259 is a spiral galaxy approximately 66 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation of Piscis Austrinus. It was discovered by John Herschel on September 28, 1834.

NGC7280.description: NGC 7280 is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation Pegasus. The galaxy lies about 75 million light years away from Earth, which means, given its apparent dimensions, that NGC 7280 is approximately 50,000 light years across.

NGC7283.description: NGC identification is very uncertain; N7283 could be a double star.

NGC7287.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7292.description: NGC 7292 is a barred irregular galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 652±24 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 31.4 ± 2.5 Mly (9.62 ± 0.76 Mpc).

NGC7293.name: Helix Nebula
NGC7293.description: The Helix Nebula (also known as NGC 7293 or Caldwell 63) is a planetary nebula (PN) located in the constellation Aquarius. Discovered by Karl Ludwig Harding, most likely before 1824, this object is one of the closest of all the bright planetary nebulae to Earth.

NGC7300.description: NGC 7300 is an intermediate spiral galaxy in the constellation of Aquarius. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 4,566±24 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 219.7 ± 15.4 Mly (67.35 ± 4.73 Mpc).

NGC7301.description: NGC 7301 is a barred spiral galaxy located around 308,000,000 light-years (94,000,000 pc) away from Earth in the constellation Aquarius. It was discovered by American astronomer Francis Preserved Leavenworth In 1886.

NGC7302.description: NGC 7302 is a lenticular galaxy located around 124 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation of Aquarius. NGC 7302 was discovered by British astronomer William Herschel on October 3, 1785 and was rediscovered by American astronomer Lewis Swift on August 8, 1896 and was listed in the IC catalogue as IC 5228.

NGC7303.description: NGC 7303 is a barred spiral galaxy around 170 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Pegasus. NGC 7303 was discovered by astronomer John Herschel on September 15, 1828.

NGC7304.description: Three Galactic stars.  NGC identification is very uncertain.

NGC7311.description: NGC 7311 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus.

NGC7312.description: NGC 7312 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 7911 ± 26 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 116.68 ± 8.18 Mpc (~381 million light-years).

NGC7314.description: NGC 7314 is a spiral galaxy located in the southern constellation of Piscis Austrinus. It was discovered by English astronomer John Herschel on July 29, 1834.

NGC7315.description: NGC 7315 is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. It was discovered on 11 September 1872 by Édouard Stephan.

NGC7317.description: NGC 7317 is an elliptical galaxy that is a member of Stephan's Quintet in the constellation Pegasus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 6272 ± 35 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 301.7 ± 21.2 Mly (92.51 ± 6.51 Mpc).

NGC7318.description: NGC 7318 (also known as UGC 12099/UGC 12100 or HCG 92d/b) is a pair of colliding galaxies about 280 million light-years from Earth. They appear in the Constellation Pegasus and are members of Stephan's Quintet.

NGC7319.description: NGC 7319 is a highly distorted barred spiral galaxy that is a  member of the compact Stephan's Quintet group located in the constellation Pegasus, some 311 megalight-years distant from the Milky Way. It was discovered on 27 September 1873 by French astronomer Édouard Stephan.

NGC7320.description: NGC 7320 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered on 27 September 1873 by French astronomer Édouard Stephan.

NGC7327.description: NGC identification is very uncertain; N7327 could be a star.

NGC7329.description: NGC 7329 is a large barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Tucana. NGC 7329 was discovered by British astronomer John Herschel in 1835.

NGC7331.description: NGC 7331, also known as Caldwell 30, is an unbarred spiral galaxy about 13.427 megaparsecs (43.79 million light-years) away in the constellation Pegasus.  It was discovered by William Herschel on 6 September 1784.

NGC7332.description: NGC 7332 is an edge-on peculiar lenticular galaxy located about 67 million light-years away in the constellation Pegasus.  It possesses a (peanut shell)-shaped bulge, associated with stellar bar.

NGC7337.description: NGC 7337 is an barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 6,255±27 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 300.9 ± 21.1 Mly (92.26 ± 6.47 Mpc).

NGC7350.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7352.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7354.description: NGC 7354 is a planetary nebula located in the northern circumpolar constellation of Cepheus, at a distance of approximately 5.5 kly from the Sun. It was discovered by German-born astronomer William Herschel on November 3, 1787.

NGC7355.description: NGC declination is -1 degree in error.

NGC7361.description: The 2MASS position refers to a knot 10 arcsec northeast of the center.

NGC7363.description: NGC 7363 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 6393 ± 24 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 	94.29 ± 6.61 Mpc (~308 million light-years).

NGC7364.description: NGC 7364 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation of Aquarius. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 4,480±26 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 215.5 ± 15.1 Mly (66.07 ± 4.64 Mpc).

NGC7380.description: NGC 7380 is a young open cluster of stars in the northern circumpolar constellation of Cepheus, discovered by Caroline Herschel in 1787. The surrounding emission nebulosity is known colloquially as the Wizard Nebula, which spans an angle of 25′.

NGC7384.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7388.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7393.description: NGC 7393 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation Aquarius. It is estimated to about 120 million light-years from the Milky Way and about 70,000 light-years in diameter.

NGC7403.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7405.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7408.description: NGC 7408 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Tucana. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 3,372±13 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 162.2 ± 11.4 Mly (49.73 ± 3.49 Mpc).

NGC7410.description: NGC 7410 is a barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Grus. It is about 122 million light-years away.

NGC7412.description: NGC 7412 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Grus. The galaxy lies about 35 million light years away from Earth based on redshift independent methods, which means, given its apparent dimensions, that NGC 7412 is approximately 40,000 light years across.

NGC7417.description: The APM position is 9 arcsec northwest of the nucleus.

NGC7418.description: NGC 7418 is an intermediate spiral galaxy located in the constellation Grus. It is located at a distance of circa 60 million light-years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7418 is about 60,000 light-years across.

NGC7419.description: NGC 7419 is an open cluster in the constellation Cepheus.  It is heavily reddened and notable for containing five red supergiants, the highest number known in any cluster until the end of the 20th century, but probably no blue supergiants.

NGC7421.description: NGC 7421 is a barred spiral galaxy in the southern constellation of Grus. It was discovered by English astronomer John Herschel on August 30, 1834.

NGC7424.description: NGC 7424 is a barred spiral galaxy located 37.5 million light-years away in the southern constellation Grus (the Crane). Its size (about 100,000 light-years) makes it similar to our own galaxy, the Milky Way.

NGC7427.description: NGC 7427 is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 9336 ± 35 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 137.70 ± 9.66 Mpc (~449 million light-years).

NGC7429.description: NGC 7429 is an open cluster in the constellation Cepheus. The object was discovered on 29 September 1829 by the British astronomer John Herschel.

NGC7436.description: NGC 7436 is a galaxy pair located in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered on December 2, 1784 by the astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7441.description: The identification as NGC 7441 is not certain.

NGC7447.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7448.description: NGC 7448 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It is located at a distance of circa 80 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7448 is about 60,000 light years across.

NGC7453.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7454.description: NGC 7454 is an elliptical galaxy in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered on October 15, 1784 by William Herschel.

NGC7456.description: NGC 7456 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation of Grus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 944±18 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 45.4 ± 3.3 Mly (13.92 ± 1.01 Mpc).

NGC7457.description: NGC 7457 is an unbarred lenticular galaxy in the constellation Pegasus. NGC 7457 is its New General Catalogue designation.

NGC7459.description: NGC 7459 is a twin spiral galaxy of magnitude 15.2 located within the constellation Pisces. It was discovered by Lewis Swift in 1886 with a 16-inch refractor.

NGC7463.description: NGC 7463 is a peculiar intermediate spiral galaxy, located in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity relative to the cosmic microwave background is 1979 ± 26 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 29.2 ± 2.1 Mpc (∼95.2 million light- years).

NGC7466.description: NGC 7466 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 7160 ± 25 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 105.60 ± 7.40 Mpc (~344 million light-years).

NGC7469.description: NGC 7469 is an intermediate spiral galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. NGC 7469 is located about 200 million light-years away from Earth, which means, given its apparent dimensions, that NGC 7469 is approximately 142,000 light-years across.

NGC7471.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7477.description: Two Galactic stars plus faint galaxy.

NGC7479.description: NGC 7479 (also known as Caldwell 44 or the Superman Galaxy) is a barred spiral galaxy about 105 million light-years away in the constellation Pegasus.  William Herschel discovered it in 1784.

NGC7481.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7486.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7492.description: NGC 7492 is a globular cluster  in the constellation Aquarius. It was discovered by the astronomer William Herschel on September 20, 1786.

NGC7493.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7496.description: NGC 7496 is a barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Grus. It is located at a distance of about 60 million light-years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that it is 75,000 light years across.

NGC7499.description: NGC 7499 is an unbarred lenticular galaxy within the constellation Pisces. NGC 7499 is its New General Catalogue designation.

NGC7501.description: NGC 7501 is an elliptical galaxy located in the constellation Pisces. It was discovered on September 2, 1864 by the astronomer Albert Marth.

NGC7502.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7503.description: NGC 7503 is an elliptical galaxy in the constellation Pisces. It was discovered by the astronomer Albert Marth on September 2, 1864.

NGC7504.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7506.description: NGC 7506 is a lenticular galaxy located about 173 million light-years away from Earth in the constellation of Pisces. It was discovered on September 20, 1784 by the astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7507.description: NGC 7507 is an elliptical galaxy located in the constellation Sculptor. It was discovered by the German-British astronomer William Herschel on October 30, 1783.

NGC7508.description: MCG notes a star or possible companion superposed.

NGC7510.description: NGC 7510 is an open cluster of stars located around 11,400 light years away in the constellation Cepheus, near the border with Cassiopeia. At this distance, the light from the cluster has undergone extinction from interstellar gas and dust equal to E(B – V) = 0.90 ± 0.02 magnitude in the UBV photometric system.

NGC7513.description: NGC 7513 is a barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Sculptor. It is located at a distance of circa 62.5 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7513 is about 75,000 light years across.

NGC7516.description: NGC 7516 is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered on September 5, 1864, by the German astronomer Albert Marth.

NGC7517.description: NGC 7517 is an elliptical galaxy located in the constellation Pisces. It was discovered on August 29, 1863, by the astronomer Albert Marth.

NGC7519.description: Position in 1991PNAOJ...2...37T is for the companion galaxy.

NGC7520.description: Nominal position for NGC 7520; nothing here.  NGC 7520 may be IC 5290.

NGC7522.description: NGC 7522 is an astronomical object whose identity is in question. It was originally catalogued as a faint nebula.

NGC7526.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7531.description: NGC 7531 is an intermediate spiral galaxy located in the constellation Grus. It is located at a distance of about 70 million light-years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7531 is about 95,000 light years across.

NGC7537.description: NGC 7537 is a spiral galaxy located in the equatorial constellation of Pisces, about 1.5° to the NNW of Gamma Piscium. It was first documented by German-born astronomer William Herschel on Aug 30, 1785.

NGC7538.description: NGC 7538, near the more famous Bubble Nebula, is located in the constellation Cepheus. It is located about 9,100 light-years from Earth.

NGC7541.description: NGC 7541 is a barred spiral galaxy located around 104 million light-years away in the constellation Pisces. It was discovered in 1785 by William Herschel, and it is 106,000 light-years across.

NGC7544.description: NGC 7544 is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation Pisces. It was discovered by the astronomer Albert Marth on November 18, 1864.

NGC7547.description: NGC 7547 is a spiral galaxy in the Pegasus constellation. It was discovered by the astronomer John Herschel on August 26, 1827.

NGC7549.description: NGC 7549 is a peculiar barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 4,373±26 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 210.4 ± 14.8 Mly (64.50 ± 4.53 Mpc).

NGC7550.description: NGC 7550 is an lenticular galaxy located in the Pegasus constellation. Its velocity relative to the cosmic microwave background is 4,598  ±  29 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 67.8 ± 4.8  Mpc (∼221  million light-years).

NGC7552.description: NGC 7552 (also known as IC 5294) is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation Grus. It is at a distance of roughly 60 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7552 is about 75,000 light years across.

NGC7555.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7572.description: NGC 7572 is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It is at a distance of about 580 million light-years away from Earth.

NGC7582.description: NGC 7582 is a spiral galaxy of the Hubble type SB(s)ab in the constellation Grus. It has an angular size of 5.0' × 2.1' and an apparent magnitude of 11.37.

NGC7583.description: NGC 7583 is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation Pisces. It was discovered on September 2, 1864 by the astronomer Albert Marth.

NGC7584.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7585.description: NGC 7585 is a lenticular galaxy with a peculiar shape resulting from an interaction between two galaxies. It is located 145 million light years away in the constellation Aquarius which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7585 is about 100,000 light years across.

NGC7590.description: NGC 7590 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Grus. This galaxy is in the upper middle west part of the Virgo Supercluster.

NGC7592.description: NGC 7592 is an interacting galaxy system located 300 million light years away in the constellation Aquarius. It was discovered by William Herschel on September 20, 1784.

NGC7599.description: NGC 7599 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation Grus. The galaxy lies about 65 million light years away from Earth based on redshift independent methods, which means, given its apparent dimensions, that NGC 7599 is approximately 95,000 light years across.

NGC7600.description: NGC 7600 is a galaxy about 160 million light-years from Earth, located in the constellation Aquarius. It is classified as a lenticular galaxy, or, more formally, an S0 galaxy.

NGC7603.description: NGC 7603 is a spiral Seyfert galaxy in the constellation Pisces. It is listed (as Arp 92) in the Atlas of Peculiar Galaxies.

NGC7606.description: NGC 7606 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Aquarius. It is located at a distance of about 100 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7606 is about 200,000 light years across.

NGC7607.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7609.description: NGC 7609 or known as Arp 150 and HCG 95A, is a large elliptical galaxy located in Pegasus. Its speed relative to the cosmic microwave background is 11,879 km/s, which corresponds the galaxy to be located 554 million light-years away from Earth (169.7 Mpc).

NGC7610.description: NGC 7610 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Pegasus. Discovered by Andrew Ainslie Common in August 1880, it was accidentally "rediscovered" by him the same month, and later given the designation NGC 7616.

NGC7611.description: NGC 7611 is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation of Pisces. Its velocity relative to the cosmic microwave background is 2,881  ±  32 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 42.5 ± 3.0  Mpc (∼139  million light- years).

NGC7612.description: NGC 7612 is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered on May 26, 1863, by the astronomer Heinrich Louis d'Arrest.

NGC7613.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7614.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7616.description: NGC 7610 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Pegasus. Discovered by Andrew Ainslie Common in August 1880, it was accidentally "rediscovered" by him the same month, and later given the designation NGC 7616.

NGC7617.description: NGC 7617 is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity relative to the cosmic microwave background is 3,801  ±  27 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 56.1 ± 4.0  Mpc (∼183  million light- years).

NGC7619.description: NGC 7619 is an elliptical galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. NGC 7619 and NGC 7626 are the dominant and brightest members of the Pegasus galaxy cluster.

NGC7623.description: NGC 7623 is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered on September 26, 1785, by the German-British astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7625.description: NGC 7625, or Arp 212, is a peculiar galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. It was discovered on October 15, 1784, by William Herschel.

NGC7626.description: NGC 7626 is an elliptical galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered on September 26, 1785, by the German-British astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7631.description: NGC 7631 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered on August 30, 1851, by the astronomer Bindon Blood Stoney.

NGC7635.name: Bubble Nebula
NGC7635.description: NGC 7635, also known as the Bubble Nebula, Sharpless 162, or Caldwell 11, is an H II region emission nebula in the constellation Cassiopeia. It lies close to the open cluster Messier 52.

NGC7637.description: NGC 7637 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation of Octans. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 3711 ± 3 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 178.5 ± 12.5 Mly (54.73 ± 3.83 Mpc).

NGC7640.description: NGC 7640 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Andromeda. Discovered on October 17, 1786 by the English astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7643.description: Identification as NGC 7644 is doubtful; N7644 may be NGC 7651.

NGC7646.description: Identification as NGC 7646 is not certain.

NGC7647.description: NGC 7647 is a giant elliptical galaxy of type cD located in the constellation Pegasus. The redshift of the galaxy is (z) 0.041 and it was discovered on November 29, 1785 by the astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7648.description: NGC 7648 is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered on October 18, 1784 by the astronomer William Herschel but also observed by astronomers Heinrich d'Arrest and Édouard Stephan.

NGC7654.description: Messier 52 or M52, also known as NGC 7654 or the Scorpion Cluster, is an open cluster of stars in the highly northern constellation of Cassiopeia. It was discovered by Charles Messier in 1774.

NGC7659.description: NGC 7659 is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation Pegasus about 173 million light-years away from Earth. It was discovered on October 16, 1784 by the astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7660.description: NGC 7660 is an elliptical galaxy located in the constellation of Pegasus. It was discovered by the astronomer John Herschel on September 5, 1828.

NGC7662.name: Copeland's Blue Snowball
NGC7662.description: NGC 7662 is a planetary nebula located in the northern constellation Andromeda. It is known as the Blue Snowball Nebula, Snowball Nebula, and Caldwell 22.

NGC7663.description: Identification as NGC 7663 is doubtful; N7663 may be MCG -01-59-022.

NGC7673.description: NGC 7673 is a disturbed spiral galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. The galaxy has experienced intense star formation activity and may therefore be referred to as a starburst galaxy.

NGC7674.description: NGC 7674 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It is located at a distance of about 350 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7674 is about 125,000 light years across.

NGC7678.description: NGC 7678 is an intermediate spiral galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It is located at a distance of about 130 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7678 is about 95,000 light years across.

NGC7679.description: NGC 7679 is a lenticular galaxy with a peculiar morphology in the constellation Pisces. It is located at a distance of about 200 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7679 is about 60,000 light years across.

NGC7680.description: NGC 7680 is a lenticular galaxy or elliptical galaxy in the constellation Pegasus. It has a magnitude of 13.

NGC7681.description: NGC 7681 is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered on October 11, 1784 by the astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7682.description: NGC 7682 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation Pisces. It is located at a distance of about 180 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7682 is about 65,000 light years across.

NGC7684.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7686.description: NGC 7686 is a moderately-sized open cluster in the constellation Andromeda, containing about 80 stars. At magnitude 5.6, it is an easy target for binoculars and small telescopes.

NGC7689.description: NGC 7689 is a intermediate spiral galaxy in the constellation of Phoenix. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 1,791±13 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 86.2 ± 6.1 Mly (26.42 ± 1.86 Mpc).

NGC7697.description: The APMUKS position is east of the nucleus.

NGC7701.description:
NGC 7701 is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation of Pisces.
It is situated close to the celestial equator making it at least partially visible on both hemispheres.

NGC7706.description: NGC 7706 is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation Pisces, first observed by British astronomer John Herschel on 16 October 1827 during his surveys of the southern and equatorial sky. Its position in the sky is near right ascension 23h 35m 10.4s and declination +04° 57′ 51″ (J2000 epoch).

NGC7707.description: NGC 7707 is a lenticular galaxy in the Andromeda constellation. It was discovered on October 24, 1786, by the astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7713.description: NGC 7713 is a barred spiral galaxy with extensive Hubble-type SBcd star-forming regions that is located in the constellation Sculptor in the southern sky. It is estimated to be 31 million light-years from the Milky Way and about 40,000 light-years in diameter.

NGC7714.description: NGC 7714 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Pisces. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 2430 ± 26 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 116.9 ± 8.3 Mly (35.85 ± 2.54 Mpc).

NGC7715.description: NGC 7714 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Pisces. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 2430 ± 26 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 116.9 ± 8.3 Mly (35.85 ± 2.54 Mpc).

NGC7716.description: NGC 7716 is an intermediate spiral galaxy located in the constellation Pisces. Its speed relative to the cosmic microwave background is 2,201 ± 26 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 32.5 ± 2.3 Mpc (~106 million ly).

NGC7720.description: NGC 7720 is an elliptical galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It is located at a distance of about 380 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7720 is about 180,000 light years across.

NGC7721.description: NGC 7721 is a spiral galaxy located around 79 million light-years away in the constellation Aquarius. NGC 7721 was discovered on September 10, 1785, by the astronomer William Herschel, and its diameter is 70,000 light-years across.

NGC7723.description: NGC 7723 is a barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Aquarius. It is located at a distance of about 90 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7723 is about 95,000 light years across.

NGC7725.description: NGC 7725 is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation Aquarius. It was discovered on September 20, 1784 by the astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7726.description: NGC 7726 is a large barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus in the northern sky. It is estimated to be 348 million light-years from the Milky Way and about 150,000 light-years in diameter.

NGC7727.description: NGC 7727 is a peculiar galaxy in the constellation Aquarius. It harbors two galactic nuclei, each containing a supermassive black hole, separated 1,600 light years apart.

NGC7730.description: Identification as NGC 7730 is not certain.

NGC7734.description: NGC 7734 is a barred spiral galaxy located in the southern constellation of Tucana. The redshift of the galaxy is (z) 0.035 and it was first discovered by an English astronomer named John Herschel on November 2, 1834, who described it as a faint small object.

NGC7735.description: NGC 7735 is an elliptical galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 9249 ± 36 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 136.41 ± 9.57 Mpc (~445 million light-years).

NGC7738.description: The NGC identification is very uncertain.

NGC7739.description: The NGC identification is very uncertain.

NGC7741.description: NGC 7741 is a barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. It is located at a distance of circa 40 million light years from Earth, which, given its apparent dimensions, means that NGC 7741 is about 50,000 light years across.

NGC7742.description: NGC 7742 (also known as the Fried Egg Galaxy) is a face-on unbarred spiral galaxy  in the constellation Pegasus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 1292 ± 26 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 62.2 ± 4.5 Mly (19.06 ± 1.39 Mpc).

NGC7752.description: NGC 7752 and NGC 7753 are a pair of galaxies approximately 272 million light-years away in the constellation Pegasus. They were discovered by R. J. Mitchell on 22 November 1854.

NGC7753.description: NGC 7752 and NGC 7753 are a pair of galaxies approximately 272 million light-years away in the constellation Pegasus. They were discovered by R. J. Mitchell on 22 November 1854.

NGC7756.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7759.description: NGC 7759 is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation Aquarius. It is located about 340 million light-years (100 megaparsecs) away from the Sun.

NGC7765.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7766.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7767.description: NGC 7767 is a 14th-magnitude lenticular galaxy located within the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered in 1872 by Ralph Copeland using Lord Rosse's 72-inch telescope.

NGC7768.description: NGC 7768 is a large elliptical galaxy located in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity relative to the cosmic microwave background is 7,663  ±  28 km /s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 113.0 ± 7.9  Mpc (∼369  million light-years).

NGC7769.description: NGC 7769 is an unbarred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Pegasus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 3855 ± 25 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 56.85 ± 4 Mpc (~185 million light-years).

NGC7770.description: NGC 7770 (also known as PGC 72635) is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation Pegasus.

NGC7771.description: NGC 7771 (also known as UGC 12815) is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Pegasus.

NGC7772.description: NGC 7772 is collection of stars in the constellation Pegasus that were thought to be an open cluster. The stars were first recorded on 7 October 1825 by the British astronomer John Herschel.

NGC7773.description: NGC 7773 is a barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation of Pegasus at an approximate distance of 400 million light years. NGC 7773 was discovered on October 9, 1790 by William Herschel.

NGC7775.description: Noted in MCG as possibly interacting.

NGC7777.description: NGC 7777 (also known as UGC 12829 and PGC 72744) is a lenticular galaxy located in the constellation Pegasus. NGC 7777 is situated north of the celestial equator and, as such, it is more easily visible from the northern hemisphere.

NGC7789.description: NGC 7789 (also known as Caroline's Rose, Caroline's Haystack, or the White Rose Cluster) is an open cluster in Cassiopeia that was discovered by Caroline Herschel in 1783. Her brother William Herschel included it in his catalog as H VI.30.

NGC7790.description: NGC 7790 is a young open cluster of stars located some 10,800 light years away from Earth in the northern constellation of Cassiopeia. At this distance, the light from the cluster has undergone extinction from interstellar gas and dust equal to E(B – V ) = 0.51 magnitude in the UBV photometric system.

NGC7791.description: This is a list of NGC objects 7001–7840 from the New General Catalogue (NGC). The astronomical catalogue is composed mainly of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.

NGC7793.description: NGC 7793 is a flocculent spiral galaxy in the southern constellation of Sculptor. It was discovered on July 14, 1826, by Scottish astronomer James Dunlop.

NGC7796.description: NGC 7796 (also known as PGC 73126) is a Elliptical galaxy in the constellation Phoenix.

NGC7797.description: NGC 7797 is a Hubble-type SAb-SAc spiral galaxy that is located in the constellation Pisces. It is estimated to be 400 million light-years from the Milky Way and has a diameter of about 115,000 light-years.

NGC7800.description: NGC 7800 is an irregular galaxy located around 70 million light-years away in the constellation Pegasus. It was discovered on the 24th of December in 1783 by William Herschel.

NGC7802.description: NGC 7802 is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation Pisces. It was discovered on September 25, 1830 by the astronomer John Herschel.

NGC7807.description: ESO RA of 23h57m5s incorrect. Corrected in ESO-LV.

NGC7808.description: NGC 7808 is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation of Cetus. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 8521 ± 24 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 125.67 ± 8.80 Mpc (~410 million light-years).

NGC7811.description: NGC 7811 is an irregular galaxy located in the constellation Pisces. It was discovered on October 5, 1864, by the astronomer Albert Marth.

NGC7812.description: NGC 7812 (also known PGC 195) as is an intermediate spiral galaxy in the constellation Sculptor. The galaxy was discovered on 25 September 1865 by Sir John Hershel.

NGC7814.description: NGC 7814 (also known as UGC 8 or Caldwell 43) is a spiral galaxy about 40 million light-years away in the constellation Pegasus.  The galaxy is seen edge-on from Earth.

NGC7816.description: NGC 7816 is a spiral galaxy located about 215 million light-years away in the constellation of Pisces. It was discovered by astronomer William Herschel on September 26, 1785.

NGC7817.description: NGC 7817 is a spiral galaxy in the Pegasus constellation. It was discovered on September 15, 1784 by the astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7818.description: NGC 7818 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Pisces. It is forming a pair with NGC 7816.

NGC7822.description: NGC 7822 is a young star forming complex in the constellation of Cepheus.  The complex encompasses the emission region designated Sharpless 171, and the young cluster of stars named Berkeley 59.

NGC7824.description: NGC 7824 is an early-type spiral galaxy located in the constellation Pisces, situated close to the celestial equator. It was discovered on September 25, 1830, by the astronomer John Herschel.NGC 7824 was Studied for its bulge, disk properties, stellar populations, and radio emissions, linking it to galaxy evolution and mass.

NGC7827.description: NGC 7827 is a lenticular galaxy (SB0 type) located in the constellation Pisces. Its other names include: PGC 378, UGC 38 or MCG+01-01-027.

NGC7828.description: NGC 7828 is a peculiar galaxy in the constellation Cetus. The galaxy lies about 300 million light years away from Earth, which means, given its apparent dimensions, that NGC 7828 is approximately 75,000 light years across.

NGC7829.description: NGC 7829 is a lenticular galaxy in the constellation Cetus. NGC 7829 was discovered by American astronomer Francis Leavenworth in 1886.

NGC7832.description: NGC 7832 is an elliptical galaxy located in the constellation Pisces. It was discovered on September 20, 1784 by the astronomer William Herschel.

NGC7840.description: NGC 7840, the last numerical entry in the New General Catalogue, is an unbarred spiral galaxy in the constellation Pisces. Its velocity with respect to the cosmic microwave background is 10906 ± 49 km/s, which corresponds to a Hubble distance of 160.85 ± 11.30 Mpc (~524 million light-years), and its diameter is about 162,000 light-years.
